Hears this sort of: once the Buddha was in the country of Kusinagara, the king was called Udayana. KusinagarağŸ”½had a Brahmin named MahÄprajÄpatÄ«, who gave birth to a daughter who was upright and beautiful, rare in the world.
The father saw the daughter's appearance, rare in the whole country, and named her AnupamÄ.
The kings of neighboring countries and the nobility of the clans all asked for her in marriage.
The father replied:
If there is a gentleman whose appearance is equal to the daughter's, I will comply.

At that time, the Buddha was traveling in that country. The Brahmin saw the Buddha's thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks, his body the color of purple gold, majestic and dignified, his radiance and demeanor unsurpassed. He was delighted and said:
My daughter has found a match.
He returned home and told his wife:
I have found a husband for AnupamÄ.
He hurriedly had the daughter dressed up and was about to go.

The couple dressed up together, and their daughter walked on the luminous flowers of jade, adorned with pearl necklaces and ornaments illuminating the country. The couple took their daughter to where the Buddha was.
On the way, the wife saw the Buddha's footprints with the patterns and radiant colors, which were not of this world. Knowing him to be the Honored One of Heaven, she said to her husband:

The patterns on this person's footprints are like this. They are not heard of in the world. He must not be an ordinary person. He must be pure and without any more sexual desires. He will certainly not accept my daughter. Do not humiliate yourself.
Her husband said:
How do you know that to be so?
The wife then spoke a verse, saying:
A lustful person drags his heels when walking, an angry person strides with pointed toes,
and a foolish person drags his feet on the ground;
these are the footprints of the Honored One of Heaven and humans.
Shengxin said:
This is not something you women can know. If you are not happy, then return home.
He then took his daughter to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
The great man is diligently teaching, but his body has no offerings.
There is this coarse woman, I wish to provide a broom and dustpan.
The Buddha said:
Do you like this woman?
She replied:
Since I gave birth to this daughter, her appearance is truly good, unmatched in the world. Many kings and nobles have asked for her, but I have not agreed.
I secretly see that the great man's radiance is majestic, unlike anything seen in the world. I covet the offerings, so I should take refuge in him.
The Buddha said:
What do you find good about this woman?
The mind of passing away said:
From head to toe, I look all over and there is nothing that is not good.
The Buddha said:
Confused indeed is the flesh eye! I look from head to toe and there is not a single good thing!ğŸ”½If there is hair on the head, it is just hair, like the tail of an elephant or horse;
below the hair is the skull, it is just bone, like the skull of a pig butcher;

The brain in the head is like a stinking mudfish, the nose is attached to the ground, and no one can step on it. The eyes are a pure juice of fragility, the nose has mucus, the mouth only has saliva, the stomach stores the liver and lungs which are also stinking, the intestines, stomach, and bladder only form feces and urine, the stench is difficult to discuss, the abdomen is a pouch wrapped in impurities, the four limbs and hands and feet are bones supporting each other, connected by tendons and covered by skin, only relying on breath to move it, it is like a wooden man whose mechanism is made, after it is finished, it is disassembled, and its body is separated joint by joint, the hands and feet are scattered.
What good is there in a human body that it is said to be rare?

Formerly, when I was under the Bodhi tree, the sixth Demon King adorned his three daughters, whose faces and complexion were unparalleled in the heavens, not to mention in this discussion, he wanted to destroy my intention to attain the Way, I spoke to them about the impurities in the body, they immediately transformed into old women's forms and left in shame.
Now, what do you want with this bag of excrement?
Take it away quickly, I don't want it.
When JÄ«vaka heard what the Buddha said, he suddenly felt ashamed and had no words to reply. He further said to the Buddha:
If you don't want it, would it be acceptable to give it to King Udayana?
The Buddha did not answer.

JÄ«vaka then sent the girl to King Udayana. The king was greatly delighted upon receiving the girl, appointed her father as his grand mentor, built a palace for her, and provided her with a thousand musicians to serve her.
The king's primary queen served the Buddha and attained the path of stream-entry.
This girl slandered her to the king, and the king, deluded by her words, shot the queen with a hundred arrows.

The queen, seeing the arrows, was not afraid and had no anger at all. With a single thought, she contemplated the Buddha's compassion and knelt for a long time facing the king. The arrows all circled around the queen three times and then returned to stand before the king. All a hundred arrows did the same.

The king was startled and frightened, so he immediately drove a white elephant and golden carriage to where the Buddha was. Before reaching the carriage, he got off and advanced on foot, bowed at the Buddha's feet, knelt for a long time and confessed:

I have a grave fault before the Three Jewels. Because of that, I followed the desires of that licentious demon and gave rise to evil thoughts towards the Buddha's noble assembly, shooting each of the Buddha's disciples with a hundred arrows. As I have confessed, I am afraid in my heart. Only the Buddha's utmost true compassion, the power of kindness of the white-robed disciples is like this, how much more so for the unsurpassed, truly enlightened Buddha?
I now repent and take refuge in the Three Jewels. I only wish that the Buddha's great compassion will forgive my faults.
The Buddha smiled and said:
Excellent, O King!
To realize evil and repent is the conduct of a wise person. I accept your good intentions.
The king bowed his head three times, and the Buddha accepted it three times.
The king then touched his head to the ground, stepped back and sat down, saying:

We receive qi, are stubborn, resentful, and self-indulgent, without a mind of patience. The three poisons are not removed, and evil conduct delights us. We follow the female demons and do not know their evil. We think that after death we will surely enter hell. We wish that the Buddha would have compassion and extensively explain the evil and demonic ways of women. Few who enter their net can extricate themselves. When we hear of their harm, we will surely warn ourselves, and the people of the country, both high and low, will be able to change their ways.
The Buddha said:
Why ask this?
Speak of other meanings.
The king said:
Speaking of other matters on another day is not too late. The great harm of the mind confused by women is that if one does not hear of their harm, how can one stay away from them?
I wish that the Buddha would fully explain to me the changes in hell and the filth of women.
The Buddha said:
Listen carefully!
The evil of men's lust, and the demons of women.
The king said:
Good! I wish to receive the clear teachings.
The Buddha said:
Listen carefully!
Men have four evils that should be urgently known.

In the world, there are licentious men who always think of seeing women and hearing seductive sounds, who abandon the true Dharma and doubt it, believing in the false, entangled in the net of lust, drowning in blindness and darkness, controlled by desire like a slave fearing the master;

Greedy for the color of women, unaware of the foul smell of the nine orifices, confused in desire, like a pig lying in filth unaware of its stench, considering it comfortable and not thinking of the pain to come in the prison of no moisture;
Focusing the mind on lust, eating their snot and saliva, enjoying their pus and blood, treasuring it like jade and relishing it like honey;
Therefore, it is said that those who indulge in lustful desires.
This is the first evil tendency.

Moreover, parents raise their children with affection, carrying them in the womb and giving birth to them. As they grow up, the hardships of nurturing are difficult to describe. When the child becomes an adult, they fear that the family wealth will be exhausted. They crawl on their knees and elbows, use matchmakers to express their feelings, and obtain a wife for them. If the wife is from a different region, they will pursue her regardless of the distance, not avoiding hardships. Their attention is focused on sex, forgetting their aging parents. Once they have obtained a wife, they cherish her like a treasure. Desiring to enjoy themselves privately, they dislike seeing their parents. Believing the deceitful words of their wife, they may even engage in quarrels, not considering the immeasurable kindness of their parents who gave birth to them.
This is called the second evil attitude.

Moreover, people in the world toil and labor to earn their own wealth. They originally have sincere faith and respect for the Way, and a heart of reverence for Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as. They realize that the world is impermanent and that giving is meritorious.

After taking a wife, one is deluded by sexual desire, foolishly obscuring oneself, turning one's back on truth and facing evil, all due to women. If one has the intention to give, although one wants to speak and call out, women cut off pure conduct and one becomes even more petty, not recognizing the precepts of the Buddha's scriptures or the return of misfortune and blessings. If one indulges in sexual desire and throws oneself into the net, one will surely fall into evil ways and never change.
This is called the three evil attitudes.

Moreover, as a son, one does not think of repaying one's parents' kindness. In earning wealth, one does not use it to support one's parents, but only seeks out sexual paths in the east and west. Carrying precious things, one attracts other people's wives and daughters, or kills the six domestic animals to engage in licentious worship of ghosts and spirits. After drinking wine, singing and dancing together, one seeks opportunities to call out to each other, in order to indulge in sexual desires. When one finds a partner, one's joy is indescribable. Bound by sexual desire, one loses all recognition.
At that time, this is the only pleasure, not aware of the foul stench of impurity and the suffering of hell, it is both laughable and frightening, like a mad dog not knowing its wrong.
This is called the four evil attitudes.
The Buddha said:
Men have these four evils, using them to fall into the three evil paths, they should carefully avoid these attitudes to escape suffering.
Listen again to the explanation of the evils of women.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Already controlled by desire, letting the mind be unable to be at ease,
Practicing giving in what is not the Dharma, what can be used to be virtuous?
Desire is the practice of animals, using desire to bring about one's own misfortune,
Like a worm in filth, not knowing it is in a difficult place.
Like a worm in darkness, not knowing east from west,
Attached to sexual desire, this evil is also a worm's discussion.
Desire not seeing the Way, day and night planting the roots of offenses,
In the present world, rulers and ministers are in chaos, and superiors and inferiors are confused and ignorant.
The king's laws are in error, and the true Dharma is in a state of confusion.
Farmers abandon their usual occupations, and merchants are entangled in treasures.
In the present world, there are more prisons, and after death, one enters Mount Tai.
One will undergo a hundred kinds of poisons, and the pain is difficult to bear.
Molten copper is poured into their mouths, and mountains crush their bodies.
There are hundreds of such cases, difficult to describe one by one.
They will always be in the three evil paths, rolling like a wheel.
If there is a Buddha in the world, they will not be able to hear him.
Women are the worst, difficult to have a relationship with.
Affection binds one, dragging people into the door of offenses.
What is good about women?
They are just bags of feces and urine. Why not carefully observe and see, and go crazy for this?
The inside is extremely foul-smelling, while the outside is adorned with a pleasing appearance,
In the home there are poisonous scorpions, as dangerous as snakes and dragons.
It is like a sword wrapped in brocade, with its sharp edge covered by a fine silk cloth,
The foolish see only the surface, and play with it to their own detriment.
The wise are aware and abandon it, while the foolish end up injured and dead,
Sexual desire is also like this, embracing a blade to bring about one's own destruction.
Seeing something new, one immediately becomes disgusted with the old, and what one delights in is also impermanent,
Words are like knives and axes cutting, and laughter is like thorns and brambles.
Inside one harbors foul-smelling poisons, while adorning the outside with flowers and incense,
Foolish people crave its taste, without considering the misfortune they will later suffer.
It is like poison from the jinn bird, mixed with the nectar of immortality,
Wherever it goes, it brings destruction. Those who drink it all fall down dead.
It is also like firewood meeting fire, or grasses and trees covered by heavy frost,
Seeing the surface without considering the inside is the most unwise.
Women's poison is even worse than this; the grass is seen to injure the form,
Cutting off desires to seek the Way, therefore there are lustful desires.
That form is very easy to see, but the deluded person's feelings are not cut off,
The net is spread on all four sides, the distance from the Way is like a hair.
People are originally of a pure lineage, like fish in a deep abyss,
The wise one then awakens himself, caught in the net he cannot return.
The net of desire is even worse than this, the bonds are very firm,
Throwing oneself onto thorns, one can escape the body.
Like a hungry monkey, seeing ripe sweet fruit,
Single-mindedly throwing oneself into lustful desires, this group falls a hundred times.
Also like a fish eating a hook, a flying moth entering a lamp,
The deluded one sees joy, not thinking of the misfortune to be received later.
The Buddha spoke thus, and King Udayana joyfully touched his head to the ground and said to the Buddha:

Indeed, since birth I have never heard that women's evils are so great. Men who are confused and follow them fall into offenses, but only because of ignorance do they not restrain their minds and intentions.
From now on, I will repent for the rest of my life, take refuge in the Three Jewels, and dare not commit offenses again.
He bowed to the Buddha and left with joy.
The Sutra of King Udayana
